docs.title: ✍️ Authored by CyberMage07
docs.text:
Welcome to the official writeup collection for the OverTheWire wargames — a series of hands-on CTF challenges designed to build practical skills in Linux, cryptography, and cybersecurity fundamentals. This site features meticulously crafted walkthroughs, step-by-step solutions, and insightful explanations for learners at all stages.

⚡ Whether you're just starting your CTF journey or brushing up on fundamentals — you're in the right place.

docs.title: ⚔️ What You’ll Find Here
docs.text: This documentation currently covers two of the most popular OverTheWire wargames:

docs.title: 🔹 Bandit
docs.text:
A beginner-friendly wargame that introduces essential Linux command-line skills like SSH, file manipulation, redirection, and permission handling.

  • ✅ 24 levels solved
  • 🔧 Pure shell-based challenges
  • 📖 Ideal for Linux beginners and CTF newcomers

docs.title: 🔹 Krypton
docs.text:
A cryptography-centric wargame focusing on classical cipher techniques like Caesar, ROT13, Substitution, Vigenère, and basic stream ciphers.

  • ✅ Levels 0 to 6 completed
  • 🔐 Hands-on cipher cracking
  • 🧩 Perfect for budding cryptanalysts

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 About the Author
docs.text:
CyberMage07 is a cybersecurity practitioner, CTF competitor, and red team enthusiast with a focus on:

  • 🔍 Offensive security & system exploitation
  • 🧠 Red Teaming
  • 🛠️ TVulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing

🧠 GitHub: CyberMage07 ✉️ Feedback and contributions are welcome via issues or pull requests.

docs.title: 🚀 How to Navigate
docs.text:
• 📚 Use the sidebar to explore Bandit and Krypton levels.
  • 🔎 Use the search bar above to jump to flags, tools, or specific commands.

💡 “Let the terminal be your playground, and curiosity your greatest tool.” — CyberMage07

Happy Hacking! ⚔️🔥

docs.title: VAPT Exploitation Cheat Sheet
docs.text: This repository serves as a one-stop guide for identifying and exploiting vulnerabilities across the OWASP Top 10 categories.

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
# Try accessing an unauthorized endpoint
curl -b "auth_token=..." http://target/admin

docs.title: 🎯 Exploitation
docs.text:
# IDOR exploitation example
curl http://target/api/user/2

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
# Check for missing HTTPS, weak ciphers
sslscan target.com

docs.title: 🎯 Exploitation
docs.text:
# Downgrade attack (if possible)
sslyze --regular target.com

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text: sqlmap -u "http://target.com/product.php?id=1" --batch --level=5 --risk=3

docs.title: 🎯 Exploitation
docs.text:
# Exploit with sqlmap to dump DB
sqlmap -u "http://target.com/product.php?id=1" --dump

docs.title: 📐 Insecure Design
docs.text:
• Manual Testing Needed:

    • Unprotected workflows

    • Weak logic in password reset

    • Lack of rate limiting

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
nuclei -u http://target.com
nikto -h http://target.com

docs.title: 🎯 Exploitation
docs.text:
# Exploit default creds if found
hydra -l admin -P rockyou.txt http://target.com/login

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
whatweb http://target.com
nmap --script vulners -sV target.com

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
# Check for missing MFA, brute-forceable logins
hydra -l admin -P rockyou.txt http://target.com/login

docs.title: 🔒 Software & Data Integrity Failures
docs.text:
• Manual and Dependency Tool Testing:

    • Check source maps, misconfigured CI/CD

    • Tools: npm audit, trivy, retire.js

docs.title: 📜 Security Logging & Monitoring Failures
docs.text:
• Detection:

    • No logs for auth events

    • Manual review required

docs.title: 🔍 Detection
docs.text:
# Common SSRF payload
curl -X POST http://target.com/fetch?url=http://127.0.0.1:80

docs.title: 🎯 Exploitation
docs.text:
# Try accessing AWS metadata
curl http://target.com/fetch?url=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/

docs.title: Level 0 → 1
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 0

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text:
The goal of this level is to log into the game using SSH. The host to which you need to connect is:

ssh bandit0@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

The password for the next level is stored in a file called readme, located in the home directory.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This challenge tests your ability to:

  • Use SSH to log into a remote Linux machine.

  • List files using ls

  • Read file contents using cat

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into the target machine using the given credentials:

    bash ssh bandit0@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

    • You’ll get a prompt to accept the server fingerprint.

    • Then, you'll be prompted for the password for user bandit0.

  2. Once logged in, list files in the current directory:

    bash ls

    • You’ll see a file named readme.

  3. Read the contents of readme using cat:

    bash cat readme

    Output:

    ZzLjTmM6FvvyRnrb2rfNWOZOTa6ip5If

    This is the password for Bandit Level 1.

  4. Logout from the session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 1:
docs.text: ZzLjTmM6FvvyRnrb2rfNWOZOTa6ip5If

docs.title: Level 1 → 2
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 1

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in a file called -. The file is located in the home directory.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches how to:

  • Handle files with names that start with special characters like -

  • Use escape techniques or double-dot prefixing to avoid command misinterpretation

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit Level 1:

    bash ssh bandit1@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

    • Use the password obtained from Level 0 (ZzLjTmM6FvvyRnrb2rfNWOZOTa6ip5If).

  2. Check the home directory contents:

    bash ls -alh

    • You'll see a suspiciously named file: -

  3. Attempt to read the file using cat - (fails):

    bash cat -

    • This treats - as STDIN, not a filename.

  4. Correct way: use relative path prefix ./ to escape the special meaning:

    bash cat ./-

    Output:

    263JGPf9u6LDtvtf6vFUW1XP5yac29mFx

    This is the password for Bandit Level 2.

  5. Exit the SSH session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 2:
docs.text: 263JGPf9u6LDtvtf6vFUW1XP5yac29mFx

docs.title: Level 10 → 11
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 10

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in the file data.txt, which contains base64 encoded text.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches:

  • Identifying and decoding base64-encoded content

  • Using the base64 command-line tool

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit10:

    bash ssh bandit10@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Check the contents of data.txt:

    bash cat data.txt

    You'll see a long base64-encoded string.

  3. Decode it using base64 -d:

    bash cat data.txt | base64 -d

    Output:

    The password is dt1eRM2zF7hvLHlH5KkZcwYHUo6YczR6

  4. Logout once done:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 11:
docs.text: dt1eRM2zF7hvLHlH5KkZcwYHUo6YczR6

docs.title: Level 11 → 12
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 11

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in the file data.txt, which contains a hex dump of a file that has been compressed repeatedly. Your task is to reverse the decompression to retrieve the password.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • Hex dumps (xxd -r)

  • Multiple compression formats: gzip, bzip2, tar

  • Extracting and working with files in /tmp

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit11:

    bash ssh bandit11@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Create and switch to a temp directory:

    bash mkdir /tmp/tempf && cd /tmp/tempf

  3. Copy the data file:

    bash cp ~/data.txt .

  4. Convert hex dump back to binary:

    bash xxd -r data.txt binary

  5. Iteratively detect and decompress formats:

    bash file binary gzip -d binary file binary bunzip2 binary file binary tar -xf binary

    Repeat this as shown in the screenshot until you reach the final readable file.

  6. Final output (from cat on the ASCII text file):

    bash cat data8

    Output:

    The password is F05wY0XDiHoRo1ZDTXWTn9V7sT1kLmgc

  7. Logout:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 12:
docs.text: F05wY0XDiHoRo1ZDTXWTn9V7sT1kLmgc

docs.title: Level 12 → 13
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 12

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in the file data.txt, but it is encrypted using OpenSSL and the AES-256-CBC cipher. The decryption password is “notexplained”.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches:

  • Decrypting files encrypted with OpenSSL using openssl enc -d

  • Understanding symmetric encryption with a passphrase

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit12:

    bash ssh bandit12@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. View file type to confirm encryption:

    bash file data.txt

    Output:

    data.txt: openssl enc'd data with salted password

  3. Decrypt using openssl:

    bash openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -in data.txt -out decrypted.txt -k notexplained

  4. Display decrypted content:

    bash cat decrypted.txt

    Output:

    55TBjpPZUUJgVP5b3BnbG6ON9uDPVzCJ

  5. Logout:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 13:
docs.text: 55TBjpPZUUJgVP5b3BnbG6ON9uDPVzCJ

docs.title: Level 13 → 14
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 13

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in etc/bandit_pass/bandit14, but you do not have permission to read it directly. However, there is a setuid binary called ./sshkey.private that will help you log in as bandit14 using SSH.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • SSH key-based login

  • Understanding and using private SSH keys

  • Running a setuid binary to escalate privileges securely

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit13:

    bash ssh bandit13@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Check for the SSH private key:

    bash ls

    Output:

    sshkey.private

  3. Set correct permissions:

    bash chmod 600 sshkey.private

  4. Use the key to login as bandit14:

    bash ssh -i sshkey.private bandit14@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  5. You’ll be logged in directly as bandit14. Now retrieve the password:

    bash cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit14

    Output:

    8ZjyCRiBWFYkneahHwxCv3wb2a1ORpYL

  6. Logout from bandit14:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 14:
docs.text: 8ZjyCRiBWFYkneahHwxCv3wb2a1ORpYL

docs.title: Level 14 → 15
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 14

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is retrieved via SSH on localhost, using a public/private key pair. You must use the provided private key to authenticate to user bandit15.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level tests:

  • Using SSH keys to log into another user’s account on localhost

  • Understanding key-based SSH authentication

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit14:

    bash ssh bandit14@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. List the private key file:

    bash ls

    You’ll see:

    sshkey.private

  3. Set the right permissions:

    bash chmod 600 sshkey.private

  4. SSH into localhost as bandit15 using the key:

    bash ssh -i sshkey.private bandit15@localhost

  5. Once logged in, read the password:

    bash cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit15

    Output:

    TLWrGzQlinKfCOmpt9ES9w2GcxZiYH79

  6. Logout from bandit15 session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 15:
docs.text: TLWrGzQlinKfCOmpt9ES9w2GcxZiYH79

docs.title: Level 2 → 3
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 2

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in a file called spaces in this filename located in the home directory.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • Filenames with spaces, which must be handled using quotes or escape characters.

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into the machine:

    bash ssh bandit2@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Check file listing:

    bash ls -alh

    You’ll see:

    spaces in this filename

  3. Read the file using quotes:

    bash cat 'spaces in this filename'

    Output:

    MNK8NHSJUi6o4IRUEDOFgFqtxPLSlSmx

  4. Logout once done:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 3:
docs.text: MNK8NHSJUi6o4IRUEDOFgFqtxPLSlSmx

docs.title: Level 3 → 4
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 3

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in a hidden file in the inhere directory.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • Navigating directories

  • Listing hidden files using ls -a

  • Understanding how . and .. work

  • Reading hidden files

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit3:

    bash ssh bandit3@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. List files and go into inhere:

    bash ls -alh cd inhere

  3. Find the hidden file:

    bash ls -alh

    Output shows a file like:

    .hidden

  4. Display the contents of the hidden file:

    bash cat .hidden

    Output:

    ZWmrDRF3JMJd3PEt1ZaaMGPhrpG0aFhF3N

  5. Logout after completing the level:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 4:
docs.text: ZWmrDRF3JMJd3PEt1ZaaMGPhrpG0aFhF3N

docs.title: Level 4 → 5
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 4

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in the only human-readable file in the inhere directory. Tip: Many files are binary, only one contains readable ASCII text.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches:

  • Using the file command to detect file types

  • Filtering human-readable (ASCII) files

  • Reading file contents via cat

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit4:

    bash ssh bandit4@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Navigate into the inhere directory:

    bash cd inhere

  3. Identify file types:

    bash file ./*

    Output (sample):

    ./-file00: data ./-file01: data ./-file02: data ... ./-file07: ASCII text ...

  4. Read the ASCII text file using escape prefix ./:

    bash cat ./-file07

    Output:

    tQKcUPy4xX0Eoo05PwT8W1BFj8BJxXxGUGUw

  5. Logout from the session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 5:
docs.text: tQKcUPy4xX0Eoo05PwT8W1BFj8BJxXxGUGUw

docs.title: Level 5 → 6
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 5

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text:
The password for the next level is stored in a file somewhere under the inhere directory and has the following properties:

  • It is human-readable

  • It is 1033 bytes in size

  • It is not executable

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level tests:

  • Using find with multiple conditions (-type, -size, -executable)

  • Filtering by file size

  • Displaying specific file content

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit5:

    bash ssh bandit5@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Search using find:

    bash find inhere -type f -size 1033c ! -executable

    Output:

    inhere/maybehere07/.file2

  3. Read the file content:

    bash cat inhere/maybehere07/.file2

    Output:

    Z7WtoNQUuWYvwM2RqxqHkUDvZwS2ONQYEw

  4. Logout from session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 6:
docs.text: Z7WtoNQUuWYvwM2RqxqHkUDvZwS2ONQYEw

docs.title: Level 6 → 7
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 6

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored somewhere on the server and has user bandit7 and group bandit6, and is 33 bytes in size.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches:

  • Deep search using find across entire filesystem

  • Filtering by user, group, and exact file size

  • Using 2>/dev/null to silence permission errors

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit6:

    bash ssh bandit6@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Run find with all required filters:

    bash find / -type f -user bandit7 -group bandit6 -size 33c 2>/dev/null

    Output:

    /var/lib/dpkg/info/bandit7.password

  3. Read the password from the file:

    bash cat /var/lib/dpkg/info/bandit7.password

    Output:

    HKBPTKQnIay4Fw76bEy8PVxKEDQRKTzs

  4. Exit the session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 7:
docs.text: HKBPTKQnIay4Fw76bEy8PVxKEDQRKTzs

docs.title: Level 7 → 8
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 7

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text:
The password for the next level is stored in the file /etc/bandit_pass/bandit8 and can be retrieved by reading the content of a file that contains the password.

But here's the twist:

You do not know the file name—you only know that it is somewhere in the home directory and contains the word "millionth".

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level focuses on:

  • Using grep to search inside files

  • Recursively scanning directories

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit7:

    bash ssh bandit7@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Search for the keyword "millionth" recursively:

    bash grep -R "millionth" .

    Output:

    ./data.txt:23r6hFYoRa9NEC0XWnSKKb4t9UQFi7rk

  3. That's the password! No need to cat — grep showed the line already.

  4. Exit session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 8:
docs.text: 23r6hFYoRa9NEC0XWnSKKb4t9UQFi7rk

docs.title: Level 8 → 9
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 8

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is the only line in the file data.txt that occurs only once.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level teaches:

  • Identifying unique lines

  • Using Unix pipelines: sort, uniq -u

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit8:

    bash ssh bandit8@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. List files and locate data.txt:

    bash ls -alh

  3. Find the unique line:

    bash cat data.txt | sort | uniq -u

    Output:

    k4CHm1TJ9iJe2PdXgGnvLAa4vxag0J0M

  4. Logout from the session:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 9:
docs.text: k4CHm1TJ9iJe2PdXgGnvLAa4vxag0J0M

docs.title: Level 9 → 10
docs.text: Challenge URL: Bandit Level 9

docs.title: 🔐 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for the next level is stored in the file data.txt in the home directory. The password is preceded by several = characters.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • Handling binary files

  • Using strings to extract printable text

  • Searching for specific patterns using grep

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Bandit9:

    bash ssh bandit9@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220

  2. Try to cat the file (not helpful due to binary content):

    bash cat data.txt | grep "="

    You'll likely see a warning like:

    grep: binary file matches

  3. Use strings to extract human-readable content:

    bash strings data.txt | grep "="

    Output:

  4. Logout from session:

    bash exit
the password is FGWmSllgJCBzE3zDE5FYh6t86EZxv3bW =================== ```

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit Level 10:
docs.text: FGWmSllgJCBzE3zDE5FYh6t86EZxv3bW

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text: The password for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to a port on localhost in the range 30000 to 31000. You will need to figure out which of these ports contains a server that will give you the next password. The programs openssl and nmap might be helpful here.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. Read current level's password from the password file:

    bash cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit15

  2. Scan open ports from 30000 to 31000 on localhost:

    bash nmap -p 30000-31000 localhost

  3. Use OpenSSL client to connect to identified SSL-enabled port and send the password:

    bash PASSWORD=$(cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit15) echo -e "$PASSWORD\n" | openssl s_client -connect localhost:30001 -quiet

  4. Retrieve the password from the server response.

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit15
PASSWORD=$(cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit15)
echo -e "$PASSWORD\n" | openssl s_client -connect localhost:30001 -quiet

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit16
docs.text: kSkVbMQ7lBYyCM4GBPvCvT1BfWRy0Dx

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text: The credentials for the next level are stored in a file called bandit17_rsa in the home directory of the current level. This file is a private SSH key, which can be used to log into bandit17@localhost.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. Check for the private key file in the home directory:

    bash ls

  2. Set appropriate permissions for the private key to prevent SSH warnings:

    bash chmod 600 bandit17_rsa

  3. Use the private key to log into bandit17:

    bash ssh -i bandit17_rsa bandit17@localhost -p 2220

  4. Retrieve the password for the next level using:

    bash cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit17

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
chmod 600 bandit17_rsa
ssh -i bandit17_rsa bandit17@localhost -p 2220
cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit17

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit17
docs.text: x2gLTTjFwMOhQ8oWNbNM362QKxfRqGLO

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text: There are two files in the home directory: passwords.old and passwords.new. The password for the next level is the only line that has been changed between the two files.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
To identify the changed line between the two files, we use the diff command:

diff passwords.old passwords.new

This compares both files line by line and displays the difference.

The line with > indicates content from passwords.new that is not present in passwords.old, i.e., the newly changed line (the password).

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text: diff passwords.old passwords.new

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit18
docs.text: x2gLTTjFwMOhQ8oWNbNM362QKxfRqGLO

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text: The password for the next level is in a file called readme located in the home directory. However, you are not logged in as bandit18 directly—any command you try to execute will be run remotely via SSH from bandit18 user.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
Since we are restricted to using commands remotely via SSH (without an interactive shell), we can use the SSH -p flag along with commands like cat to read the file.

  1. Try listing files remotely (just for confirmation):

    bash ssh bandit18@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220 'ls'

  2. Read the readme file remotely:

    bash ssh bandit18@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220 'cat readme'

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text: ssh bandit18@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220 'cat readme'

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit19
docs.text: GWpM2hKXVmUDUNgPAVJBwYuGHYn9zL3j8

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text:
To gain access to the next level, you must run a setuid binary (bandit20-do) that will execute your command as the bandit20 user.

You do not have direct access to the bandit20 password file, so the binary must be used to read it.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. List files in the home directory to check the special binary:

    bash ls -alh

    Output:

    -rwsr-x--- 1 bandit20 bandit19 ... bandit20-do

  2. Use the bandit20-do binary to run cat on the password file for bandit20.

  3. The command:

    bash ./bandit20-do cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit20

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text: ./bandit20-do cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit20

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit20
docs.text: oQXahG8ZjoVMN9Ghs7iOWsCfZyXOUbYO

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text:
A program is listening on port XXXX (localhost only) and will give the password for the next level if the right password is sent to it.

The previous password is the input it expects.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. First, start a Netcat listener to inspect how the binary behaves:

    bash nc -lvnp 4444

  2. Execute the binary suconnect with a port number:

    bash ./suconnect 4444

    On wrong password input, it returns:

    ERROR: This doesn't match the current password!

  3. Then run with the correct previous password (Bandit20 password):

    bash ./suconnect 4444

    From the nc terminal, input the password:

    oQXahG8ZjoVMN9Ghs7iOWsCfZyXOUbYO

  4. If correct, you'll get:

    Password matches, sending next password

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
nc -lvnp 4444
./suconnect 4444
# Then input: oQXahG8ZjoVMN9Ghs7iOWsCfZyXOUbYO

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit21
docs.text: EeoULMcra2q0dSKyJ56lDX7s1CpBu0Bt

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text: A cronjob is running every minute on the server as user bandit22. It is copying a password file to a location only readable by bandit22. Your task is to find out where it puts the file, and read it.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. Go to the cron directory for bandit22:

    bash cd /etc/cron.d

  2. View the cronjob script:

    bash cat cronjob_bandit22

    Output:

    * * * * * bandit22 /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit22.sh

  3. Inspect the cron script:

    bash cat /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit22.sh

    Output:

    ```bash

  4. Read the password from the temporary file:

    bash cat /tmp/0

docs.title: !/bin/bash
docs.text: chmod 777 /tmp/0 cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit22 > /tmp/0 ```

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
cat /etc/cron.d/cronjob_bandit22
cat /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit22.sh
cat /tmp/0

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit22
docs.text: GbKksEFF4yrVs6il55v6gwY5aVje5f0j

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text:
A cronjob is running every minute on the server as user bandit23. It executes a script that looks in a specific directory for new files, executes them, and deletes them afterward.

Your task is to place a script in that directory which outputs the password for Bandit23 into a file you can read.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. View the cron job:

    bash cat /etc/cron.d/cronjob_bandit23

    Output:

    * * * * * bandit23 /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit23.sh

  2. Read the cronjob script:

    bash cat /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit23.sh

    Output:

    ```bash

  3. Create a script inside /var/spool/bandit22/:

    bash echo 'cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit23 > /tmp/shaunpass' > /var/spool/bandit22/my_script.sh chmod +x /var/spool/bandit22/my_script.sh

  4. Wait 1 minute, then read the output:

    bash cat /tmp/shaunpass

docs.title: !/bin/bash
docs.text: for i in /var/spool/bandit22/*; do bash "$i" 2>/dev/null rm -f "$i" done ```

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
echo 'cat /etc/bandit_pass/bandit23 > /tmp/shaunpass' > /var/spool/bandit22/my_script.sh
chmod +x /var/spool/bandit22/my_script.sh
cat /tmp/shaunpass

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit23
docs.text: jbYICExggBDSA5XESyphPTQ9L7ZgWn1i

docs.title: Level 23 → 24
docs.text: Awesome! Here's the final writeup for this batch:

docs.title: 🧩 Challenge Description
docs.text:
A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, as user bandit24. It deletes all scripts in a specific directory (/var/spool/bandit24) and executes only one script — /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit24.sh.

Your task is to read the script, understand what it does, and leak the password from /etc/bandit_pass/bandit24.

docs.title: 🧪 Solution Strategy
docs.text:
1. Check the cron job definition:

    bash cat /etc/cron.d/cronjob_bandit24

    Output:

    * * * * * bandit24 /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit24.sh

  2. Read the cron job script:

    bash cat /usr/bin/cronjob_bandit24.sh

    Output:

    ```bash

  3. Understand that the script generates a hash based on:

    bash echo "I am user bandit24" | md5sum

    Output:

    9a2c8e5d6ecbdedd312be69ed170fcdb

  4. Use the hash to read the password file:

    bash cat /tmp/9a2c8e5d6ecbdedd312be69ed170fcdb

docs.title: !/bin/bash
docs.text: myname=$(whoami) mytarget=$(echo I am user $myname | md5sum | cut -d ' ' -f1) echo "Copying passwordfile /etc/bandit_pass/$myname to /tmp/$mytarget" cp /etc/bandit_pass/$myname /tmp/$mytarget ```

docs.title: ✅ Commands Used
docs.text:
echo "I am user bandit24" | md5sum
cat /tmp/9a2c8e5d6ecbdedd312be69ed170fcdb

docs.title: 🔑 Password for Bandit24
docs.text: UoMYTrfrBFHyQXmg6gzctqAwOmw1IohZ

docs.title: Level 2 → 3
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 2

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for krypton3 is stored in the file /krypton/krypton2/krypton3, encrypted using a Caesar cipher — a basic letter-shifting technique.

docs.title: 📚 Concept:
docs.text:
In this level, you’ll practice:

  • Decrypting a Caesar Cipher

  • Brute-forcing 26 rotations (shifts)

  • Recognizing meaningful output from a decoded string

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 2:

    bash ssh krypton2@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: ROTTEN

  2. Read the encrypted file:

    bash cat /krypton/krypton2/krypton3

    Output:

    OMQEMDUEQMEK

  3. Use Python to brute-force Caesar shift:

    ```python import string

    charset = string.ascii_uppercase enc = "OMQEMDUEQMEK"

    for k in range(26): dec = "" for c in enc: if c in charset: idx = charset.find(c) idx = (idx + k) % 26 dec += charset[idx] else: dec += c print(f"{k:02d}: {dec}") ```

    One of the outputs will be:

    12: CAESARISEASY

  4. Logout once you get the password:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 3:
docs.text: CAESARISEASY

docs.title: Level 6 → 7
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 6

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for krypton7 is encrypted using a stream cipher. You’re provided a compiled binary (encrypt6) that encrypts input using a repeating key + random seed, and the original ciphertext is already known.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • The concept of stream ciphers

  • Performing a known plaintext attack

  • Observing pattern repetitions to deduce encryption weaknesses

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 6:

    bash ssh krypton6@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: RANDOM

  2. Navigate to the directory:

    bash cd /krypton/krypton6/ ls

    Files available:

    HINT1 HINT2 README encrypt6 keyfile.dat krypton7 onetime

  3. View the encrypted password:

    bash cat krypton7

    Output:

    PNUKLYLWRQKGKBE

  4. Generate test ciphertext with known plaintext:

    Create a plaintext of repeating characters and encrypt it:

    bash python3 -c "print('A'*100)" > /tmp/plain.txt ./encrypt6 /tmp/plain.txt /tmp/cipher.txt cat /tmp/cipher.txt

    Output:

    EICTDGYIYZKTHNSIRFXYCPFUEOCKRN...

    Notice the repeated 30-character pattern — the stream cipher’s key repeats every 30 bytes!

  5. Repeat with another character (e.g., 'B') to verify offset change:

    bash python3 -c "print('B'*100)" > /tmp/plain2.txt ./encrypt6 /tmp/plain2.txt /tmp/cipher2.txt cat /tmp/cipher2.txt

    Compare differences to isolate the XOR pattern.

  6. XOR the known ciphertext with the observed keystream to recover the plaintext:

    ```python cipher = "PNUKLYLWRQKGKBE" key = "EICTDGYIYZKTHNS" # Extracted from encrypting 'A'*30

    for i in range(len(cipher)): k = ord(cipher[i]) - ord(key[i]) if k < 0: k += 26 k += ord('A') print(chr(k), end='') ```

    Output:

    LFSRISNOTRANDOM

  7. Logout:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 7:
docs.text: LFSRISNOTRANDOM

docs.title: Level 0 → 1
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 0

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: Log into krypton1 using SSH. The password is stored in a file called level0, which is base64 encoded.

docs.title: 📘 Concept:
docs.text:
In this level, you'll get hands-on with:

  • Basic SSH authentication

  • Reading file contents with cat

  • Decoding base64-encoded strings using CLI tools

docs.title: 🔧 Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 1:

    bash ssh krypton1@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: Provided externally or captured from earlier

  2. View the base64 encoded file:

    bash cat level0

    Output:

    S1JZUFRPTklTR1JFQVQ=

  3. Decode using base64:

    bash echo "S1JZUFRPTklTR1JFQVQ=" | base64 -d

    Output:

    KRYPTONISGREAT

  4. Logout:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 1:
docs.text: KRYPTONISGREAT

docs.title: Level 1 → 2
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 1

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: Find the password for krypton2. It is located in the file /krypton/krypton1/krypton2 and encrypted using a rotation cipher (ROT13).

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level demonstrates:

  • Reading files from another path

  • Using ROT13 substitution ciphers

  • Simple character translation in shell

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 1:

    bash ssh krypton1@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: KRYPTONISGREAT

  2. Display the encrypted file:

    bash cat /krypton/krypton1/krypton2

    Output:

    YRIRY GJB CNFFJBEQ EBGGRA

  3. Use the tr command for ROT13 decryption:

    bash echo "YRIRY GJB CNFFJBEQ EBGGRA" | tr 'A-Za-z' 'N-ZA-Mn-za-m'

    Output:

    LEVEL TWO PASSWORD ROTTEN

  4. Logout after completion:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 2:
docs.text: ROTTEN

docs.title: Level 4 → 5
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 4

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for krypton5 is stored in a file named krypton5. It was encrypted using a Vigenère cipher with a known key length of 6, and you are given two reference plaintexts (found1, found2) to help derive the key.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This challenge focuses on:

  • Understanding polyalphabetic substitution ciphers

  • Cracking Vigenère ciphers

  • Using frequency analysis on repeated intervals

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 4:

    bash ssh krypton4@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: BRUTE

  2. Navigate to the correct directory and list files:

    bash cd /krypton/krypton4/ ls

    You’ll see:

    HINT README found1 found2 krypton5

  3. Read the encrypted file:

    bash cat krypton5

    Output:

    HCIKV RJOX

  4. Use frequency analysis to find the key:

    Since key length is 6, we split the ciphertext into 6 separate columns and analyze each as a Caesar cipher:

    A Python approach was used to analyze each position's frequency and match it with English frequency norms.

    After decoding and verifying through mapping:

    ✅ Derived key: FREKEY

  5. Decrypt the final ciphertext using the derived key with a Vigenère decoder.

    Output:

    CLEARTEXT

  6. Logout after completing:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 5:
docs.text: CLEARTEXT

docs.title: Level 5 → 6
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 5

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for krypton6 is encrypted with a Vigenère cipher, just like the previous level. This time, however, the key length is unknown, and your job is to deduce it before decrypting the message.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
This level introduces:

  • Key-length detection in Vigenère ciphers

  • Trial-and-error for Caesar shift alignment

  • Leveraging intuition and repetition to validate plaintext

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 5:

    bash ssh krypton5@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: CLEARTEXT

  2. Navigate to the challenge directory:

    bash cd /krypton/krypton5/ ls

    Files available:

    README found1 found2 found3 krypton6

  3. Read the encrypted password file:

    bash cat krypton6

    Output:

    BELOS Z

  4. Try different key lengths and analyze shifts:

    Reuse the script from Level 4 and adjust the key length until a readable plaintext appears.

    Eventually, the output:

    RANDOM

    was found when the guessed key was:

    KEYLENGTH

    (A clever pun by the challenge author 👀)

  5. Logout:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 6:
docs.text: RANDOM

docs.title: Level 3 → 4
docs.text: Challenge URL: Krypton Level 3

docs.title: 🎯 Level Goal:
docs.text: The password for krypton4 is hidden inside an encrypted file using a monoalphabetic substitution cipher. You are also provided with 3 plaintext clue files that were encrypted using the same cipher key.

docs.title: 🧠 Concept:
docs.text:
In this level, you’ll work with:

  • Frequency analysis of ciphered letters

  • Decrypting monoalphabetic substitution ciphers

  • Pattern recognition across multiple files

docs.title: 🛠️ Steps to Solve:
docs.text:
1. SSH into Krypton Level 3:

    bash ssh krypton3@krypton.labs.overthewire.org -p 2222

    Password: CAESARISEASY

  2. Navigate to the challenge directory:

    bash cd /krypton/krypton3/ ls

    Files present:

    HINT1 HINT2 README found1 found2 found3 krypton4

  3. View the encrypted password file:

    bash cat krypton4

    Output:

    KSVVW BGSJD SVSIS VXBMN YQUUK BNWCU ANMJS

  4. Combine and analyze frequency of known ciphertext samples:

    bash cat found1 found2 found3 | tr -d ' ' | fold -w1 | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr

    Result:

    (S, Q, J, U...) are most frequent letters

    Based on this and comparing with English letter frequency (ETAOIN...), we can start mapping likely substitutions.

  5. Use a Python script to apply the frequency-based mapping:

    ```python cipher = "KSVVWBGSJDSVSISVXBMNYQUUKBNWCUANMJS" mapping_from = "SQJUBNCGDZVWMYTXKELAFIOHRP" mapping_to = "EQTSORINHCLDUPMFWGYBKVXQJZ"

    cleartext = "" for c in cipher: if c in mapping_from: i = mapping_from.index(c) cleartext += mapping_to[i] else: cleartext += c

    print(cleartext) ```

    Output:

    WELLDONETHELEVELFOURPASSWORDISBRUTE

  6. Logout once complete:

    bash exit

docs.title: 🗝️ Password for Krypton Level 4:
docs.text: BRUTE
